connectionStrings.expirationWarning: Your hub connection string is expiring in less than {{numberOfDays}} day(s). Please edit the connection string (by copying and pasting again) to extend, or you would have to re-add it once it expires.

symmetricKey.secondaryConnectionStringTooltip: Connection string based on secondary key used in API calls which allows device to communicate with IoT Hub
symmetricKey.secondaryKeyTooltip: The secondary symmetric shared access key stored in base64 format

ca.text: This device is being authenticated through a CA Certificate.
ca.connectionStringTooltip: Connection string used in API calls which allows device to communicate with IoT Hub

selfSigned.text: This device is being authenticated using an X.509 certificate.
selfSigned.primaryThumbprintTooltip: The primary X.509 thumbprint representing the SHA-1 or SHA-256 hash of the X.509 certificate. Thumbprint values other than 40 hex characters for SHA-1 and 64 hex characters for SHA-256 are not accepted.
selfSigned.secondaryThumbprintTooltip: The secondary X.509 thumbprint representing the SHA-1 or SHA-256 hash of the X.509 certificate. Thumbprint values other than 40 hex characters for SHA-1 and 64 hex characters for SHA-256 are not accepted.
selfSigned.connectionStringTooltip: Connection string used in API calls which allows device to communicate with IoT Hub

sasToken.toolTip: Generate a connection string using a SAS token

confirmationDialog.title: Delete from IoT Hub?
confirmationDialog.subText: Review carefully. You are about to remove the following device(s) from your IoT hub and may have consequences for others using the same Hub or device(s).

deviceTwin.tooltip: You can add tags and desired properties to your device twin here. To remove a tag or desired property, set the value of the item to be removed to 'null'.

digitalTwin.modelContainsNoComponents: Model '{{modelId}}' contains no IoT Plug and Play components

steps.zero: Your device is not recognized as a IoT Plug and Play device. To learn more, please check out
steps.first: Step 1. Your device has been discovered as a IoT Plug and Play device
steps.secondSuccess: Step 2. We've resolved your IoT Plug and Play model
steps.secondFailure: Step 2. We are not able to retrieve model definition for {{modelId}}
steps.third: Step 3. Continue your IoT Plug and Play journey by drilling down to each component
steps.explanation: If you have defined 'Property', 'Command' or 'Telemetry' in model {{modelId}}, you would be able to see 'Default component' in the table below. If you have defined 'Component', you would be able to see a list of components down below.

deviceProperties.noProperties: ComponentName {{componentName}} contains no read-only property definitions

editor.label: Property schema '{{schema}}' is not yet supported in UI forms. Please use the JSON editor below to view reported value

deviceSettings.noPreviewContent: There is no payload to show.
deviceSettings.noSettings: ComponentName {{componentName}} contains no writable property definitions

columns.name: Name (Display Name / Description)
columns.reportedValueTooltip: Reported value is updated asynchronously. Please click 'Refresh' button on the top to get latest value manually

columns.source: You model definition has been resolved from

deviceInterfaces.interfaceNotFound: We are not able to retrieve any valid interface model definition. Please click 'Configure' button below to see how we resolve model definition.
deviceInterfaces.interfaceNotValid: Model definition is not valid. Please update the model definition and then proceed.
deviceInterfaces.interfaceListFailedToRender: Failed to parse component list from the model definition. It may contain definitions that we don't support at this point. Please visit our wiki to check the scope of DTDL we support: https://github.com/Azure/azure-iot-explorer/wiki

consumerGroups.label: Consumer group
consumerGroups.tooltip: Consumer groups are used by applications to pull data from the IoT Hub. To change the current consumer group, stop monitoring telemetry.

connectionString.label: Custom event hub connection string
connectionString.error: Event hub connection string format should look like 'Endpoint=sb://<FQDN>/;SharedAccessKeyName=<KeyName>;SharedAccessKey=<KeyValue>'

deviceEvents.tooltip: You can monitor telemetry that the device sends to the IoT hub

key.isNotSpecified: This telemetry '{{key}}' is not in the model. You may consider modeling it.
key.doesNotMatch: Key mismatch. Expected key is {{expectedKey}}, but received is {{receivedKey}}

simulation.header: Simulate a device using CLI in Azure Cloud Shell

cloudShell.textDescription: Click Launch Cloud Shell, paste the commands below to simulate a device sending telemetry. You will be able to start monitoring events from the built-in event hub.

prerequisite.label: Prerequisite
prerequisite.tooltiop: If you have not used Azure Cloud Shell before
prerequisite.instruction: Follow the instructions in Azure Cloud Shell to pick a subscription and set up a storage if you haven't used Cloud Shell before. If you have encountered error 'az iot: 'device' is not in the 'az iot' command group', use command 'az extension add --name azure-iot' to install Azure IoT CLI extension.

basic.label: Basic scenario
basic.instruction: Simply copy paste the following command to Azure Cloud Shell. It will start simulating device {{deviceId}} as it's sending messages to IoT Hub. You can click 'Start' button from the Telemetry page to start monitoring the events.

advanced.label: Advanced scenario
advanced.tooltiop: For advanced users to simulate events' body or properties
advanced.instruction: Enter the desired message body and/or properties, and copy paste the generated command to Azure Cloud Shell. It will start simulating device {{deviceId}} as it's sending messages to IoT Hub. You can click 'Start' button from the Telemetry page to start monitoring the events.

body.label: Provide event body
body.tooltip: If left empty, the default value would be: 'Ping from Az CLI IoT Extension'.

directMethod.tooltip: You can send direct methods to a device. Direct methods have a name, payload, and configurable connection and method timeouts.
directMethod.methodNamePlaceHolder: The name of the Direct method to invoke on this device
directMethod.connectionTimeoutTooltip: Number of seconds to wait until a connection is successfully made.
directMethod.responseTimeoutTooltip: Number of seconds to wait until a result is received from the Direct method.
directMethod.payloadTooltip: The payload for the Direct method to invoke on the device

cloudToDeviceMessage.tooltip: You can send messages to a device in your IoT Hub. Messages have both a body and optional properties organized as a collection of key/value string pairs.
cloudToDeviceMessage.bodyTooltip: The body of the message to send to the device.

properties.label: Properties

ack.full: Full (IoT Hub generates a feedback message in either case)
ack.positive: Positive (If the c2d message reaches the Completed state, IoT Hub generates a feedback message)
ack.negative: Negative (If the c2d message reaches the Dead lettered state, IoT Hub generates a feedback message)

contentType.description: The content type associated with the message body.

contentEncoding.description: The content encoding associated with the message body.

correlationId.description: The correlation Id associated with the message.

expiryTimeUtc.description: Expiry time in UTC in milliseconds since unix epoch.
expiryTimeUtc.error: Expiry time must be an integer and greater than now

lockToken.description: Used to Abandon, Reject or Accept the message.

messageId.description: The message Id. If no message Id is provided a UUID will be generated.

properties.tooltip: The properties of the message to be sent to this device.

moduleIdentity.tooltip: You can create up to 20 module identities. Each module identity implicitly generates a module twin
moduleIdentity.noModules: There are no module identities for this device.
moduleIdentity.errorFetching: An error prevented this information from being loaded.
moduleIdentity.moduleIdTooltip: Module identity name used for authentication and access control.

symmetricKey.primaryKeyTooltip: The primary symmetric shared access key stored in base64 format
symmetricKey.secondaryKeyTooltip: The secondary symmetric shared access key stored in base64 format

selfSigned.text: This device is being authenticated using an X.509 certificate.
selfSigned.primaryThumbprintTooltip: The primary X.509 thumbprint representing the SHA-1 or SHA-256 hash of the X.509 certificate. Thumbprint values other than 40 hex characters for SHA-1 and 64 hex characters for SHA-256 are not accepted.
selfSigned.secondaryThumbprintTooltip: The secondary X.509 thumbprint representing the SHA-1 or SHA-256 hash of the X.509 certificate. Thumbprint values other than 40 hex characters for SHA-1 and 64 hex characters for SHA-256 are not accepted.

notifications.connectionStringsWithoutExpiryRemovalWar: Due to security requirments, previously stored hub connection strings have been removed. The new connection string being added would automatically have an expiration date one year from now.
notifications.connectionStringsWithExpiryRemovalWarnin: Due to security requirments, one or more hub connection strings stored more than a year ago have been removed.

empty.header: No model repository locations to display
empty.description: Model repository locations specify where the application looks to find IoT Plug and Play model definitions. Locations are saved to application storage and can be edited or removed at any time by returning
empty.help: What is IoT Plug and Play

modelRepository.instruction: We'll look for your model definition in the following order. Please drag and drop to change it. Click 'Add' to enable more ways to can resolve your model definitions.

addLocalSource.label: Local folder
addLocalSource.labelInBrowser: Local folder (This is only enabled in the desktop version from: https://github.com/Azure/azure-iot-explorer/releases)
addLocalSource.ariaLabel: Add local folder as model source

help.label: Help
help.ariaLabel: Open browser tab to IoT Plug and Play documentation

local.label: Local Folder
local.infoText: Use your local folder as a model repository. The model definition files you wish to use should have a json extension. The first JSON file with an '@id' property matching the digital twin model identifier (DTMI) will be retrieved.

dialog.title: Select a folder as a local model repository
